post_title: Startups Weekly: Big shake-ups at the AI heavyweights
title: Big Shake-Ups at AI Heavyweights: Stability AI, Microsoft, and More
post_content:
Welcome to the Startup Sphere — a curated digest of the week's unmissable events in the startup world. Don't miss out; subscribe to receive this roundup directly in your inbox every Friday.

This week has been relatively quiet on my end, but behind the scenes, the gears are turning at full speed in preparation for the TechCrunch Early Stage event in Boston on April 25. It promises to be an insightful gathering, and there's still a chance to secure tickets at a discounted rate.

Top Startup Stories of the Week

Stability AI's Leadership Shuffle: Stability AI waves goodbye to its founder and CEO, Emad Mostaque, who has set his sights on the decentralized AI frontier. The company, notorious for its rapid cash consumption, is now under the temporary leadership of co-CEOs Shan Shan Wong and Christian Laforte. Mostaque's departure is framed as a crusade against "centralized AI," shifting the narrative from fears of autonomous AI to concerns over control and ownership.

Microsoft's Strategic Acquisition: In a move reminiscent of a cinematic caper, Microsoft has acquired the co-founders and key personnel of Inflection AI, along with the rights to their technology, for a staggering $650 million. The transaction, which appears more like a strategic purchase than a typical acquisition, ensures Inflection won't pursue legal action against Microsoft for this bold move. Reid Hoffman, a Microsoft board member and Inflection co-founder, reassures stakeholders of a satisfactory return on investment, although the figures suggest a modest outcome.

Data Privacy Breaches:
Meta, formerly known as Facebook, has been implicated in "Project Ghostbusters," an undercover initiative aimed at decrypting Snapchat's secure traffic to analyze user behavior and gain a market advantage.

Robinhood's Financial Innovations:
Robinhood introduces its Gold Card, offering a range of benefits that could give the Apple Card a run for its money. Membership in Robinhood Gold, priced at $5 monthly, unlocks significant cashback rewards on purchases.

Nvidia's Unexpected Pivot:
Nvidia, alongside Amazon Web Services (AWS), may have inadvertently discovered their niche. AWS capitalized on selling its internal storage and computing services, while Nvidia's gaming GPUs found a new purpose in AI processing.

Weekly Trend Spotlight: Transportation Woes

Fisker's Stock Market Exit:
The New York Stock Exchange has delisted EV maker Fisker due to its significantly low share prices. The company's financial stability is in question following a sharp stock price drop, rumored failed negotiations with Nissan, and a loan repayment clause they're struggling to meet.

Canoo's Acquisition of Arrival's Assets:
Bankrupt EV company Arrival has sold its remaining assets to Canoo, another electric vehicle company on shaky ground. The transaction seems driven by necessity rather than innovation, as Canoo attempts to assemble a production line from Arrival's discounted offerings.

Lordstown Motors' Legal Settlement:
Steve Burns, the former head of the now-bankrupt Lordstown Motors, has reached a settlement with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission regarding misleading claims about the demand for their all-electric Endurance pickup truck.
meta_desc:
Discover the latest news and insights in the startup world with Startup Sphere – your essential weekly digest. Subscribe now to receive this roundup of unmissable events straight to your inbox every Friday.

Top Startup Stories of the Week

 Stability AI undergoes leadership changes: Emad Mostaque steps down as CEO, citing concerns over centralized AI control and ownership.
 Microsoft acquires Inflection AI and key personnel for $650 million, sparking debate about strategic purchase versus traditional acquisition.
 Data privacy breaches at Meta (Facebook) come to light in "Project Ghostbusters," an undercover initiative aimed at analyzing Snapchat user behavior.
 Robinhood introduces the Gold Card, offering significant cashback rewards and membership benefits for $5 monthly.
 Nvidia pivots to AI processing, following in the footsteps of AWS in selling internal storage and computing services.

Weekly Trend Spotlight: Transportation Woes

 Fisker delisted from the New York Stock Exchange due to low share prices and financial instability.
 Canoo acquires Arrival's remaining assets, driven by necessity rather than innovation, to assemble a production line for electric vehicles.
 Lordstown Motors reaches a settlement with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission over misleading claims about demand for their all-electric pickup truck.

post_title: MIT tool shows climate change could cost Texans a month and a half of outdoor time by 2080
title:
SEO Title: "Climate Change: Mitigating Its Impact on Agriculture, Insurance and More"

Cleaned Instructions:

Climate change is a significant issue that has an impact on agriculture, insurance, and other industries. The loss of outdoor days due to climate change varies depending on the region, with some areas experiencing a clement climate while others are facing droughts, floods, and storms. To mitigate the impact of climate change, it is crucial to reduce carbon emissions and transition to renewable energy sources. By taking action, we can make a difference in our communities and contribute to a global effort to address this crisis.
post_content:
Cleaned Instructions:

The task is to clean up a piece of text by removing any non-English text, advertisements, or author attributions. The text must also be corrected for grammatical errors, typos, or awkward phrasing. The core message and factual accuracy of the text must be maintained.

Rewritten Instructions:

Write a blog post that discusses the concept of climate change and its impact on the world. Use a catchy title and opening sentence to grab the reader's attention. Discuss the different ways that climate change can be described, including global warming, climate change, and climate crisis. Provide examples of how climate change has affected various regions, including California, France, Germany, and the UK. Use data and statistics to support your claims.

Discuss the importance of climate change and its impact on the world. Use examples to illustrate how climate change has affected different regions and demographics. Provide specific examples of how climate change has affected agriculture, insurance, and other industries. Discuss the importance of understanding the impact of climate change and how it can be mitigated.

Use a personal anecdote to illustrate the importance of climate change. Discuss the different ways that climate change can be addressed, including reducing carbon emissions and transitioning to renewable energy sources. Provide examples of how individuals can make a difference in mitigating the impact of climate change.

Conclude the blog post by summarizing the importance of addressing climate change and the steps that can be taken to mitigate its impact. Encourage readers to take action and make a difference in their communities.

Output Format:

Introduction:

Climate change is a hot topic in the news today, but how do we truly understand what it is and how it's affecting the world? In this blog post, we'll explore the different ways that climate change can be described and the impact it has on various regions and demographics. We'll also discuss the importance of understanding the impact of climate change and how it can be mitigated.

Body:

Climate change is a complex concept that can be described in different ways, including global warming, climate change, and climate crisis. While these terms may have different connotations, they all refer to the same phenomenon: the gradual warming of the Earth's climate. The effects of climate change are varied and far-reaching, impacting different regions and demographics in different ways.

In California, the climate is becoming more clement, with an added month or two of outdoor weather compared with historical records. However, in New York, Massachusetts, China, and Japan, the loss of a week or more of outdoor days is a concern. For countries like Nigeria and India, the effects of climate change are even more dire, with nearly two months and almost two and a half months of outdoor days lost, respectively.

Climate change has a significant impact on agriculture, insurance, and other industries. For example, droughts, floods, and storms have decimated crops, leading to water risk assessments and other weather and climate-related data. Insurance companies are also using climate forecasting to provide customers with options to insure their outings against inclement weather.

Conclusion:

Climate change is a serious issue that requires immediate action. By reducing carbon emissions and transitioning to renewable energy sources, we can mitigate the impact of climate change and make a difference in our communities. Whether it's through personal actions or collective efforts, we all have a role to play in addressing this global crisis.
meta_desc:
Title: Understanding Climate Change: Its Effects and How to Mitigate Them

Meta Description: Discover the different ways climate change can be described and its impact on various regions and industries. Learn how to mitigate its effects and make a difference in your community.

post_title: Why AWS, Google and Oracle are backing the Valkey Redis fork
title: "Open-Source Redis Fork Backed by AWS, Google, and Oracle"
post_content:
The Linux Foundation has announced that it will host Valkey, a fork of the Redis in-memory data store. Valkey is backed by AWS, Google Cloud, Oracle, Ericsson, and Snap, and aims to provide businesses with an open-source alternative to the commercial version of Redis offered by Redis Labs.

AWS and Google Cloud rarely back an open-source fork together, but when Redis Labs switched Redis away from the permissive 3-clause BSD license to the more restrictive Server Side Public License (SSPL) in March, a fork was always one of the most likely outcomes. The new license required commercial agreements to offer Redis-as-a-service, making it incompatible with the standard definition of “open source.”

Redis, which was launched in 2009 by Salvatore Sanfilippo under the BSD license, has seen several licensing disputes throughout its history. After Redis quickly gained popularity, Garantia became the first major Redis service provider, but Sanfilippo and the community pushed back. In 2021, Redis Labs changed its name to Redis, and Sanfilippo transferred his IP to Redis Labs/Redis before stepping down from the company in 2020. That was only a couple of years after Redis changed how it licensed its Redis Modules, which include visualization tools, a client SDK, and more. For those modules, Redis first went with the Apache License with the added Commons Clause that restricts others from selling and hosting these modules.

Redis’ Trollope reiterated that the large cloud vendors profited from the open-source version and are free to enter a commercial agreement with Redis. He emphasized that the major cloud service providers have all benefited commercially from the Redis open-source project, and they are free to establish fair licensing agreements with Redis Inc. Microsoft has already come to an agreement, and Redis is open to creating similar relationships with AWS and GCP.

Valkey was initiated by AWS, and it originated from a GitHub account of longtime Redis maintainer Madelyn Olson. Redis maintainers from Redis initially decided to move on when the news of the license change broke, but they later signed on to Valkey. The original Redis private channel included five maintainers, including
meta_desc:
Title: Valkey: An Open-Source Fork of Redis Backed by Major Cloud Service Providers

Meta Description: Valkey, a new open-source fork of Redis backed by AWS, Google Cloud, Oracle, Ericsson, and Snap, aims to provide businesses with an open-source alternative to the commercial version of Redis offered by Redis Labs. The fork has already garnered support from the Redis community and will be hosted on GitHub. The source code of Valkey will be available under the Apache Software License (ASL) with the added Commons Clause.
focuskeywords:
AWS, Google Cloud, Oracle, Ericsson, and Snap, and they expressed their views on the licensing change. Valkey aims to provide businesses with an open-source alternative to the commercial version of Redis offered by Redis Labs.

Valkey is not a new fork, as Redis was already forked several times before. The main difference is that Valkey is backed by major cloud service providers, which is not common. Valkey also aims to provide a more permissive license that is closer to the original BSD license.

Valkey's development will be led by Madelyn Olson and Redis maintainers, and the community is welcome to contribute. Valkey will be hosted on GitHub, and the source code will be available under the Apache Software License (ASL) with the added Commons Clause.

Redis Labs has not responded to Valkey's announcement, but it is unlikely to challenge the open-source version of Redis. The company has already initiated a legal challenge against Redis Inc., which is Redis Labs' parent company, over the licensing change. Redis Inc. has accused Redis Labs of failing to provide the community with a sufficient notice of the change before the license change was made.

In conclusion, Valkey is a new open-source fork of Redis backed by major cloud service providers, including AWS, Google Cloud, Oracle, Ericsson, and Snap. Valkey aims to provide businesses with an open-source alternative to the commercial version of Redis offered by Redis Labs. The fork has already garnered support from the Redis community, and its development will be led by Madelyn Olson and Redis maintainers. The source code of Valkey will be available under the Apache Software License (ASL) with the added Commons Clause.

post_title: Iron Sheepdog is fixing short-haul trucking from the bottom up
title: Revolutionize Short-Haul Trucking with Iron Sheepdog: A Technology-Driven Solution.
post_content:
The short-haul trucking industry is often plagued by inefficiencies and a lack of transparency. Iron Sheepdog, a technology company based in Williamsburg, Virginia, aims to change this by providing a seamless and user-friendly platform that connects contractors with short-haul truckers. The company's software allows companies to track their contracted trucks in real-time, providing them with more transparency into where trucks are, how long a job takes, and how much to pay. The truckers themselves get an easy-to-use app that helps them accept jobs and get paid online.

Iron Sheepdog has been able to see rapid growth in recent years, with a double-digit increase in adoption each year since its founding. This success can be attributed to the company's approach to building technology that prioritizes ease of use and adoption. Unlike its competitors, Iron Sheepdog started with the short-haul truck drivers themselves, creating a simple app that tied to 24-hour pay. This approach has led to a substantial number of brokers and truckers using the platform, allowing companies to better utilize these resources.

With the recent $10 million Series B round led by SJF Ventures, Iron Sheepdog is now looking to scale its operations and continue to innovate in the short-haul trucking space. The company's focus on adoption and ease of use has set it apart from its competitors and has contributed to its success. As the short-haul trucking industry continues to grow, Iron Sheepdog's platform is poised to play a critical role in making the industry more efficient and transparent.
meta_desc: Optimize short-haul trucking technology for transparency - Iron Sheepdog.

post_title: Ember's journey from hot coffee to medication transport
title: Ember's journey from hot coffee to temperature-controlled solutions
post_content:
Ember has come a long way since its initial Indiegogo campaign in 2015. The company has since expanded its product line beyond its popular smart mug to include a shipping box for temperature-controlled items, such as medicines and baby bottles. With a focus on creating innovative solutions for everyday problems, Ember has become a leader in the consumer technology industry.

Ember’s beginnings can be traced back to the frustration of a lukewarm cup of coffee. Founder Clay Alexander, a self-proclaimed coffee aficionado, set out to create a product that would maintain the perfect temperature of his favorite brew from first sip to last. However, bringing Ember to life was no easy feat. As a hardware startup, Ember faced numerous challenges, including high product development and manufacturing costs and complex IP protection and international expansion.

Despite these obstacles, Alexander remained steadfast and assembled a team of engineers, designers, and marketers who shared his passion for creating a product that would enhance the coffee-drinking experience. After extensive research and development, Ember settled on a sleek, minimalist design that seamlessly integrated the heating technology into the mug. The mug also features wireless charging, customizable temperature settings, and a smartphone app that allows users to control it remotely.

Once a product was developed, hardware startups face significant upfront investment in materials, tooling, and manufacturing processes, putting immense pressure on startups to secure funding and generate revenue. Ember's success can be attributed to its ability to navigate these challenges and create a product that truly solves a problem.

Intellectual property protection is another challenge faced by hardware startups. Securing patents and trademarks can be time-consuming and expensive, requiring careful strategizing and prioritization. One of Ember's biggest challenges came when it was approached by one of the world's largest and most influential retailers, who wanted to expand its product line beyond the U.S. However, the retailer did not like localized launches, and Alexander had to fly up to Cupertino multiple times to pass all of their tests before the product was launched in the Apple store.

Overall, Ember's success can be attributed to its ability to navigate the challenges faced by hardware startups and create a product that truly solves a problem. With a focus on innovation and a commitment to excell
meta_desc:
Ember: Enhancing everyday problems with innovative solutions

Are you tired of lukewarm coffee or transporting medication with too much hassle? Look no further than Ember, a leader in consumer technology. From their popular smart mug to temperature-controlled shipping boxes, Ember has created innovative solutions for everyday problems. With a sleek, minimalist design and wireless charging, Ember has become a must-have for coffee aficionados and busy professionals alike. Visit Ember's website today to learn more about their products and find the perfect solution for your needs.
focuskeywords:
Ember's journey from hot coffee to medication transport

post_title: Women in AI: Kate Devlin of King's College is researching AI and intimacy
title: "AI & Intimacy: Kate Devlin's Exploration of Ethical Implications"
post_content:
TechCrunch is launching a series of interviews highlighting remarkable women who have contributed to the AI revolution. These profiles will showcase key work that is often overlooked, and the series will continue throughout the year as the AI industry continues to grow. Check out more profiles here.

Kate Devlin is one of the women being featured in this series. She is a lecturer in AI and society at King's College London and the author of "Turned On: Science, Sex and Robots," which explores the ethical and social implications of technology and intimacy. Her research focuses on how people interact with and react to technologies, both past and future.

Devlin is also the founder of the United Kingdom's first sex tech hackathon and is a board member of the Open Rights Group, an organization that works to preserve digital rights and freedoms. She directs advocacy and engagement for the Trusted Autonomous Systems Hub, a platform that supports the development of socially beneficial robotics and AI systems.

In this interview, Devlin discusses her start in AI, the work she is most proud of, and the challenges she faces as a woman in a male-dominated industry. She also shares her advice for women seeking to enter the field and discusses some of the most pressing issues facing AI as it evolves.

Devlin emphasizes the importance of responsibility and accountability when building AI, and encourages investors to push for responsible practices in the industry. She also highlights the need for regulation and a strong conscience when it comes to developing AI that benefits society as a whole.

Overall, Devlin's interview provides valuable insights into the world of AI and the opportunities and challenges that come with it. Her passion for the field and commitment to ethical and socially responsible practices make her a valuable voice in the AI industry.
meta_desc: Discover the remarkable contributions of Kate Devlin, an AI and society researcher and founder of the UK's first sex tech hackathon. Get her advice on entering the field and learn about the pressing issues facing AI. Read the full interview here.
focuskeywords: AI and Intimacy researcher Kate Devlin.

post_title: Robinhood's new Gold Card, BaaS challenges and the tiny startup that caught Stripe's eye
title: "Robinhood's Gold Card, BaaS Challenges & TechCrunch Fintech's Highlights"
post_content:
In this week's edition of TechCrunch Fintech, we delve into the latest developments in the fintech industry. We take a closer look at Robinhood's new Gold Card and its impressive features, including cash back and the ability to invest that cash back. We also discuss the challenges facing the banking-as-a-service (BaaS) space, with layoffs and consent orders affecting several VC-backed companies.
Additionally, we explore new investments in the FinTech industry, including PayPal Ventures' investment in Qoala and New Retirement's $20 million funding. We also catch up on the latest developments at Zaver, a B2C buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) provider in Europe.
In our "What Else We're Writing" section, we take a closer look at how a tiny startup, Supaglue, caught Stripe's eye. We also discuss the latest developments at Bolt, with Justin Grooms taking over as interim CEO after former CEO Maju Kuruvilla stepped down.
Our "High-Interest Headlines" section features a range of intriguing stories, including an investigation into Mercury's stumble from fintech hero to target of the feds and a look at how RealPage and Plaid are working to curb rental fraud.
Overall, this week's edition of TechCrunch Fintech provides a comprehensive overview of the latest developments in the FinTech industry, with engaging and informative content that is sure to captivate readers.

title: "OpenAI Launches Voice-Cloning Tool with Safeguards for Election Season"
post_content:
The rise of AI-powered deepfakes has been a major concern in recent times, especially with the upcoming election year. OpenAI has developed a voice-cloning tool that can mimic someone's speech based on a 15-second audio sample. While this technology presents significant benefits, it also poses serious risks, as demonstrated by the political consultant who created an AI-generated robocall impersonating Joe Biden. OpenAI is cautiously launching their tool and working with partners from various sectors to ensure that safeguards are in place to prevent the misuse of this technology.

Disinformation researchers are concerned that the proliferation of voice-cloning tools could lead to widespread misinformation in the 2024 White House race and other key elections around the globe this year. OpenAI is taking a responsible approach and implementing safety measures, including watermarking to trace the origin of any audio generated by their tool and proactive monitoring of its use. Partners testing Voice Engine agreed to rules such as requiring explicit and informed consent of any person whose voice is duplicated using the tool. It's important to note that audiences must also be made aware when voices they are hearing are AI-generated.

The potential for synthetic voice misuse is too great to ignore. OpenAI is taking a cautious and informed approach to the broader release of Voice Engine, recognizing the risks involved in generating speech that resembles people's voices. While this technology presents new opportunities, it also requires careful consideration and regulation to prevent its misuse and protect the integrity of democratic processes. As we approach the upcoming election year, it's critical to remain vigilant and take proactive measures to prevent the spread of disinformation.
meta_desc: "AI-generated voice misuse poses serious risks in upcoming elections. OpenAI is launching Voice Engine tool with safeguards to prevent misuse. Learn more and become informed. AI voicecloning electionsecurity"
focuskeywords: The keyphrase for this news article is: "AI-generated voice misuse."

post_title: This Week in AI: Let us not forget the humble data annotator
title: "Labeling and Annotation Startups: Addressing Criticism and Ensuring Fair Treatment of Annotators"
post_content:
In the ever-evolving world of AI, it is essential to keep up with the latest developments in machine learning and related research. One such development is the rise of labeling and annotation startups, which play a crucial role in the training of AI models. However, these platforms often face criticism due to the working conditions and low wages afforded to annotators.

Labeling and annotation startups such as Scale AI, which is reportedly in talks to raise new funds at a $13 billion valuation, are vital to the success of modern AI models. These platforms require thousands to millions of labels for training data sets, and the accuracy and quality of labels significantly impact the performance and reliability of the models.

Annotators are responsible for labeling data, such as marking objects or providing captions in images. However, the working conditions of annotators, including low wages and limited benefits, are often criticized. Some annotation and labeling platforms have relied on contractors in third-world countries, who are exposed to disturbing content and lack access to mental health resources.

One such platform, Scale AI, recruits annotators in countries as far-flung as Nairobi and Kenya, where some tasks take multiple workdays and pay as little as $10. Annotators are also subject to the whims of the platform and may go long periods without receiving work or be unceremoniously booted off the platform.

To address these issues, policymaking may be the best shot at improving working conditions for annotators. However, policymaking is a challenging prospect, and there are currently no regulations or industry standards for ethical labeling work. Companies' own definitions of ethical labeling work vary widely, and some platforms claim to provide "fair-trade" work, which is not always regulated.

In conclusion, labeling and annotation platforms play a crucial role in the success of modern AI models. However, the working conditions and low wages afforded to annotators are often criticized, and policymaking may be necessary to address these issues. It is essential to ensure that AI models are trained on high-quality labeled data while treating annotators fairly and providing them with living wages and benefits.
meta_desc: Improve your AI model's performance by providing top-notch labeled data. However, the working conditions and low wages afforded to annotators are often criticized. Policymaking may be necessary to address these issues and ensure that annotators are treated fairly and receive living wages and benefits.

post_title: The market is forcing cloud vendors to relax data egress fees
title:
Cloud vendors, including Amazon, Microsoft, and Google, have recently relaxed their egress fees, which are fees charged to customers who want to move their data to another vendor. This move may seem like a gesture of goodwill, but it is still protectionism that can create friction and hinder customer satisfaction.

The shift towards a more competitive cloud market is driven by changing market dynamics and regulatory pressure. As true competition heats up, cloud providers need to be seen as less restrictive and more transparent. Giving customers what they want is now the right business strategy.

The emergence of a multi-cloud world is another factor driving this change. As enterprise customers demand greater flexibility and ease of movement between cloud providers, egress fees can become a significant barrier to data sharing and collaboration.

Rudina Seseri, the founder of Glasswing Ventures, agrees that regulatory pressure plays a role in this shift. However, she also notes that Google has used this move as a marketing tool to paint itself as the "less restrictive" cloud provider, attracting early-stage customers.

David Linthicum, a cloud consultant, warns customers to review their bills carefully as egress fees are just one part of the overall cost of cloud services. There are other hidden fees and costs associated with cloud services that can add up quickly.

The experience of startups will improve as providers focus on innovative features and improved customer satisfaction to win long-term loyalty. However, larger enterprise customers may still face challenges in unwinding their tightly built infrastructures.

Graham, CEO of Bobsled, sees this change as a positive step towards a more open and flexible cloud ecosystem. While he believes that egress fees may not completely disappear, he sees a future where it becomes increasingly difficult to determine what is an egress fee and what isn't.

Overall, the relaxation of egress fees marks a significant shift in the cloud market, driven by changing market dynamics, regulatory pressure, and the need for greater flexibility and ease of movement between cloud providers. As cloud providers continue to evolve and innovate, customers can expect to see more changes and improvements in the way they move and manage their data.
post_content:
The big three cloud vendors, Amazon, Microsoft, and Google, have recently relaxed their egress fees, which are essentially a tax that cloud companies charge customers to move their data to another vendor. While this move may seem like a gesture of goodwill, it is still a form of protectionism that can create friction and hinder customer satisfaction.

John Dinsdale, the chief analyst and managing director at Synergy Research, a firm that tracks the cloud infrastructure market, believes that this change in market dynamics is a natural progression. "As true competition heats up, it would do cloud providers no good to be seen as being overly protectionist," Dinsdale says.

Giving customers what they want is now the right business strategy, according to Dinsdale. Legacy companies that cling to outdated ways of doing things will not do well in the IT world of the last few years. This shift towards a more competitive cloud market is essential for cloud providers to remain relevant and retain their customers.

The emergence of a multi-cloud world is another factor driving this change. As enterprise customers demand greater flexibility and ease of movement between cloud providers, egress fees can become a significant barrier to data sharing and collaboration. This can be especially challenging in a global enterprise environment where multiple platforms are used.

Rudina Seseri, the founder and managing partner at Glasswing Ventures, agrees that regulatory pressure plays a role in this shift. However, she also points out that Google has used this move as a marketing tool to paint itself as the "less restrictive" cloud provider, attracting early-stage customers.

David Linthicum, a cloud consultant, warns customers to review their bills carefully. While egress fees may be phased out, other hidden fees and costs associated with cloud services can add up quickly.

The experience of startups will improve as providers focus on innovative features and improved customer satisfaction to win long-term loyalty. However, larger enterprise customers may still face challenges in unwinding their tightly built infrastructures.

Graham, whose business revolves around helping customers move data, sees this change as a positive step towards a more open and flexible cloud ecosystem. While he still believes that egress fees may not completely disappear, he sees a future where it becomes increasingly difficult to determine what is an egress fee and what isn't.

Overall, the relaxation of egress fees marks a significant shift in the cloud market, driven by changing market dynamics, regulatory pressure, and the need for greater flexibility and ease of movement between cloud providers. As cloud providers continue to evolve and innovate, customers can expect to see more changes and improvements in the way they move and manage their data.
meta_desc:
makes it hard for customers to compare prices and make informed decisions.

The shift towards a multi-cloud world is driving cloud providers to become more transparent and open in their pricing and service offerings. This is good news for customers who want more flexibility and ease of movement between cloud providers. However, it also means that egress fees are just one part of the overall cost of cloud services, and customers need to understand the full picture before making a decision.

Cloud consulting expert David Linthicum advises customers to review their bills carefully and understand the different types of fees associated with cloud services. He also suggests that customers negotiate with their vendors to get better pricing and service.

The future of the cloud industry is one of innovation and flexibility, with providers focusing on innovative features and improved customer satisfaction to win long-term loyalty. However, larger enterprise customers may still face challenges in unwinding their tightly built infrastructures.

In conclusion, the recent changes in egress fees are a significant shift in the cloud market, driven by changing market dynamics, regulatory pressure, and the need for greater flexibility and ease of movement between cloud providers. As cloud providers continue to evolve and innovate, customers can expect to see more changes and improvements in the way they move and manage their data.

post_title: TikTok ban could harm Amazon sellers looking for alternatives
title: TikTok's E-commerce Dreams in Limbo: How Amazon Sellers Are Impacted
post_content:
TikTok an e-commerce force to be reckoned with

The U.S. government's decision to possibly ban TikTok could have a significant impact on the Chinese app's e-commerce dreams, as well as the smaller merchants who have flocked to the platform in search of new channels. In recent months, TikTok has been growing its focus on e-commerce, with many sellers from China using the app's TikTok Shop to sell clothes, cosmetics, electronics, and a variety of other products to U.S. buyers. However, the interplay of tech giants and geopolitics is making it difficult for these merchants to operate on TikTok, as they are unsure about the app's future in the U.S.

According to research from Jungle Scout, an Amazon data intelligence provider, 20% of Amazon sellers, brands, and businesses plan to expand to TikTok Shop this year. Before the current political backlash took off, ByteDance reportedly projected that it could grow its U.S. e-commerce business tenfold to $17.5 billion this year. TikTok is not the only platform on the list for merchants looking for more channels beyond Amazon to expand their customer bases, as platforms like Temu are also gaining attention. Amazon is reportedly taking notice, another sign that alternatives are picking up traction.

TikTok has been trying to boost its e-commerce business since its U.S. launch in September 2023. The app has a strong dose of curation, with a focus on branded goods, making it a direct competitor to Amazon. TikTok also offers incentives and algorithms to encourage merchants to sell goods on the platform. According to a survey from Tabcut, a Chinese firm that tracks TikTok Shop performance, nearly 70% of sellers reported an increase in sales year-over-year for the first 11 months of 2023. TikTok has the opportunity to reshape how America's younger generations shop online.

TikTok has been doing some pretty bold media spinning to push its message, including a report by Oxford Economics that estimated that a presence on the platform led to $14.7 billion in revenues for the 7 million SMBs in the U.S. using it. However, the app's future in the U.S. is uncertain due to the current political climate, and merchants who have flocked to the platform are unsure about what the future holds.

TikTok's e-commerce dreams could be cut short if the U.S. government decides to ban the app, which would leave smaller merchants seeking new channels without a viable option. The app's focus on branded goods and traditional subsidies could make it more difficult for small merchants to compete on the platform, leaving them with fewer options to grow their businesses.

In conclusion, TikTok's e-commerce dreams could be cut short if the U.S. government decides to ban the app, leaving smaller merchants seeking new channels without a viable option. The app's focus on branded goods and traditional subsidies could make it more difficult for small merchants to compete on the platform, leaving them with fewer options to grow their businesses. TikTok is not the only platform on the list for merchants looking for more channels beyond Amazon to expand their customer bases, as platforms like Temu are also gaining attention. Amazon is reportedly taking notice, another sign that alternatives are picking up traction.

post_title: An optimization-based method to enhance autonomous parking
title: Autonomous Parking Optimization: Enhancing Safety with OCEAN Planner
post_content:
Welcome to our blog post on the latest advancements in autonomous parking technology. In recent years, researchers have been exploring the possibility of so-called "automated valet parking" (AVP), an application of autonomous driving that would allow a car to drive itself from the entrance of a parking lot to a free parking spot. While AVP has garnered substantial research interest, the reliable realization of this technology has so far proven challenging.

In this article, we will discuss a recent study by a team of researchers at Mach Drive in Shanghai, who developed an innovative Openspace Collision-freE trAjectory plaNner (OCEAN) for autonomous parking. This planner, which is described in a paper pre-published on arXiv, was found to significantly enhance the ability of cars to safely reach a parking spot without colliding with objects on the way.

The OCEAN planner was designed to overcome two primary shortcomings of approaches presented in previous studies on autonomous parking. The first of these is the inability to accurately predict collisions, while the second involves poor performance in real-time tests. The researchers built on a previously introduced approach called Hybrid Optimization-based Collision Avoidance (H-OBCA), addressing its primary limitations.

The improved design of the OCEAN planner ultimately enhances its ability to avoid collisions, along with its robustness and speed in real-time tests. The planner was tested on hundreds of simulated scenarios and conducted real-world experiments in public parking areas. The results were highly promising, as OCEAN was found to outperform a variety of methods for autonomous parking applications.

The researchers argue that their planner could be improved and tested in additional real-world trials. In the future, it could be deployed by automotive companies, contributing to the introduction of automated vehicle parking technologies.

If you're interested in learning more about autonomous parking technology, check out our blog post on the topic. We cover everything from the benefits of autonomous parking to the challenges it presents.

Stay tuned for more exciting updates on the latest developments in autonomous driving technology.
meta_desc:
Autonomous parking technology: Shanghai researchers develop an innovative planner for AVP

post_title: Simultaneous performance improvement and energy savings with an innovative algorithm for 6G vision services
title: "Deep Learning-Based 6G Mobile Vision Services Optimized with Integrated Learning Model and Resource Optimization Algorithm"
post_content:
Title: Professor Jeongho Kwak's New Integrated Learning Model and Resource Optimization Algorithm for 6G Mobile Vision Services

Are you ready to transform your mobile vision services with the power of augmented reality (AR) and autonomous driving? The 6G mobile vision services have been receiving significant attention in recent years for their ability to capture and understand videos and images through deep learning-based models.

However, these services require high-performance processors (GPUs) and accurate learning models, which can be challenging to optimize. Previous technologies treated learning models and computing/networking resources as separate entities, leading to inefficient resource utilization and suboptimal performance.

To address this issue, Professor Jeongho Kwak from the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at DGIST has developed a new integrated learning model and computing/networking optimization algorithm, VisionScaling. This algorithm is designed to reduce energy consumption by at least 30% while maintaining average accuracy compared to current technologies without compromising on average target accuracy or time delay.

The VisionScaling algorithm developed by Professor Kwak's team uses 'Online Convex Optimization (OCO),' one of the latest learning techniques, to adapt to constantly changing mobile environments and maintain optimal performance even without prior knowledge of future conditions.

Furthermore, Professor Kwak's team implemented and tested the real-world mobile vision service environment using embedded AI devices and connected edge computing platforms. They confirmed that the developed VisionScaling algorithm saves 30% more energy in mobile devices and improves end-to-end latency by 39% compared to previously used algorithms.

The research is published in the IEEE Internet of Things Journal, providing a technical foundation for deep learning-based mobile services requiring higher memory/computing resources in the future. This research satisfies both the practical contribution of implementing and verifying performance in irregularly changing mobile environments and the mathematical contribution of utilizing dynamic optimization and learning techniques to prove optimal performance.

In conclusion, the development of VisionScaling, an integrated learning model and computing/networking optimization algorithm, is a significant step towards optimizing resource utilization and achieving high-performance 6G mobile vision services. With the increasing demand for AR and autonomous driving services, this technology will be crucial in providing accurate and efficient mobile vision services in the future.
meta_desc: Optimize your 6G mobile vision services with Professor Jeongho Kwak's new algorithm. His team has developed an integrated learning model and resource optimization algorithm, VisionScaling, that reduces energy consumption and improves end-to-end latency by 39%. With the power of deep learning, this algorithm is essential for providing accurate and efficient mobile vision services in the future. Try it today!

post_title: Fisker loses customers' money, Robinhood launches a credit card, and Google generates travel itineraries
title: "Fisker Loses Money, Facebook's "Project Ghostbusters," AI Itineraries & More - TechCrunch Week in Review"
post_content:
Welcome to this week’s TechCrunch Week in Review (WiR), where we distill the most fascinating tech stories of the past few days into a compact, engaging format for your reading pleasure.

Fisker's Rocky Road
TechCrunch’s auto reporter, Sean O’Kane, revealed that EV startup Fisker temporarily lost track of millions of dollars in customer payments as it scaled up deliveries. The internal audit that followed took months to complete, highlighting the company's challenges in managing financial processes during rapid growth.

Facebook's "Project Ghostbusters"
In other news, Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai reported on Facebook's secret project, known internally as “Project Ghostbusters.” The social media giant attempted to intercept and decrypt Snapchat’s network traffic, igniting privacy concerns and sparking debates on ethical business practices.

Shake-ups at Stability AI
Manish Singh wrote about the resignation of Stability AI founder and CEO Emad Mostaque amid struggles for stability at the company. Stability AI, the startup behind the popular image generation tool Stable Diffusion, was reportedly spending $8 million a month with little revenue, leaving many to question its business model.

Other Notable News

 Fisker’s stock trading was halted due to abnormally low stock levels.
 Google’s Search Generative Experience now offers AI-powered travel itineraries.
 Robinhood launched its new Gold Card, leveraging X1’s technology.
 AT&T has yet to explain the release of 73 million customers' personal information online.

Funding Spotlight

 Copilot, the budgeting app, raised $6 million in a Series A round.
 Liquid Death, the canned water startup, secured $67 million in a recent fundraising round.
 PipeDreams, a software solution for HVAC and plumbing companies, raised $25 million.

Analysis: Is Nvidia the Next AWS?
Ron Miller discussed the parallels between Nvidia’s and AWS’ growth trajectories, raising questions about Nvidia’s potential role as a dominant player in the cloud computing space.

Podcast Highlights

 Equity: Robinhood’s new credit card, Fisker’s woes, and Databricks’ AI model.
 Found: Allison Wolff on wildfire management and fostering lower-burning fires.
 Chain Reaction: Jacquelyn’s interview with Scott Dykstra on Space and Time’s verifiable compute layer for web3.

Spotify Explores Online Learning
In a bid to engage its 600 million+ users, Spotify is testing an e-learning platform featuring freemium video courses. This move reflects the streaming giant’s continued efforts to expand its offerings and deepen user engagement.

Stay tuned for next week’s WiR, and sign up to receive the Week in Review newsletter in your inbox every Saturday.
meta_desc: Meta Description: Discover the latest tech news, including Fisker's financial struggles, Facebook's "Project Ghostbusters," and Stability AI's business model woes. Stay up-to-date with the week's funding spotlight and analysis, as well as the latest podcast highlights. Sign up for our newsletter to receive the Week in Review every Saturday.

post_title: Microsoft Copilot has reportedly been blocked on all Congress-owned devices
title: "Microsoft Copilot Blocked on Congress-Owned Devices: Balancing Innovation with Security"
post_content:
The Changing Landscape of AI Tools in Government Operations

In a world where artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly intertwined with daily tasks, the U.S. Congress has taken a cautious step back. A recent report from Axios has brought to light a memo from Catherine Szpindor, the House Chief Administrative Officer, which marks a significant shift in the use of AI chatbots by Congressional staff. The memo outlines a clear directive: Microsoft's Copilot is no longer permitted on government-issued devices.

This decision stems from concerns raised by the Office of Cybersecurity, which flagged Copilot as a potential risk for leaking sensitive House data to cloud services that lack House approval. While staff members are not barred from using Copilot on personal devices, the AI chatbot will be inaccessible on all Windows devices provided by Congress.

The move echoes a similar restriction placed nearly a year prior on ChatGPT, another AI tool developed by OpenAI. In that instance, the free version of ChatGPT was banned from House computers, though the paid version, ChatGPT Plus, was allowed to remain in use for its enhanced privacy measures, facilitating research and evaluation tasks.

The White House has also weighed in on the matter, establishing guidelines for federal agencies regarding the use of generative AI. These guidelines are designed to protect the rights and safety of American citizens, ensuring that AI tools do not pose a threat to these fundamental principles.

Microsoft's response to the concerns has been one of understanding and adaptation. Recognizing the need for heightened security in government operations, the tech giant has unveiled a suite of tools and services tailored for government use. This includes an Azure OpenAI service capable of managing classified workloads and a revamped version of the Microsoft 365 Copilot assistant, both boasting advanced security features suitable for sensitive data handling.

As the landscape of AI in government continues to evolve, Szpindor's office remains vigilant. The government-specific version of Copilot is under consideration, with a thorough evaluation to precede any decision on its deployment on House devices. This careful approach reflects a broader trend of balancing innovation with security, as AI becomes an ever-present factor in the fabric of governance.
meta_desc: Improve your productivity with Microsoft's Copilot chatbot on personal devices, but not government-issued ones. Copilot has been blocked on Congress-owned devices due to security concerns, but the tech giant is working to address these concerns and offer secure AI solutions for government use. Keep your organization secure with Microsoft's advanced security features.
focuskeywords: The keyphrase for this news article is "Microsoft Copilot Blocked on Congress-owned Devices".
